body: By the way, I changed the title. Hopefully it's reasonable.
Review by @ijuma.
@guozhangwang Good point. I did change `KafkaStreams#cleanUp()` to be "task sensitive" now. This make unit-testing the method not possible any longer -- also removed this test. /cc @dguy

Thanks for the comments. I really don't have a good sense for whether the increase in GC time from Becket's tests is a concern or not. It's also difficult to tell how common this deadlock would be in practice, so it's tough deciding whether to include this or not, though it would definitely be a bit odd to justify deadlock potential in the code on account of performance.

For comparison, here is an alternative approach that I considered which doesn't depend on copying: https://github.com/confluentinc/kafka/pull/109. It's a little more complex, but the intuition is that you probably only need one thread at any given time trying to complete or purge operations.

Mutable default arguments are shared by all instances (if not overridden). In this case, the `settings` argument was being modified for SSL in one of the quota tests (or another like it), which caused the SSL configuration to mistakenly propagate to the throttling tests, which use plaintext.

Test run with quota tests executing before throttling tests: http://testing.confluent.io/confluent-kafka-branch-builder-system-test-results/?prefix=2016-10-01--001.1475363113--hachikuji--hotfix-producer-perf-service--4666586/.
LGTM
Merged to trunk and 0.10.1.

@hachikuji I think leaving a deadlock not fixed is worse than having some performance impact. Personally I think the current patch is fine, because we rarely see 10000 produce or fetch requests per second. Even if that happens, very likely the bottleneck is not the purgatory. I am not sure about the impact of GC time either, though.

I am a little concerned about the alternative approach. Is it possible for an added operation to be missed if `tryComplete()` simply return when fail to lock? Especially given that `watch()` is not synchronized anymore.

Yep, I agree with that we better spend much time for validating this change.
I know you're doing really busy as the manager of next release. I always appreciate your help!
The patch LGTM. This patch is targeted for 0.10.1.0. ping @ijuma

LGTM - only potential issue i can think of is if you multiple instances on the one machine and 1 or more are running and 1 is doing cleanup. If they share the same state dir, then all the task dirs will be deleted. However, i think this is probably more a case of documenting that scenario?
Hi @dguy . Thank you for your reply. I am willing to continue. I will check the changes from KIP-63 and continue accordingly.
reopen
Ping @hachikuji for review.
LGTM. Thanks for the patch!
Tests passed locally, merged to 0.10.1 and trunk branches.
@mjsax Is this still true with the latest patch?
Discussed with @hachikuji offline and we think this issue deserves a better solution, while this PR itself is not perfectly resolving it while introducing other issues. So closing it for now.
LGTM.
LGTM provided that the tests pass. Left a couple of trivial comments that don't require re-review.
LGTM
Tests passed locally, merged to trunk and 0.10.1 branches.
LGTM
Merged to trunk and 0.10.1 with a minor tweak.
Thanks for the patch! LGTM.
Merged to trunk and 0.10.1 with a minor doc tweak.
Minor comment, otherwise LGTM.

@dguy @guozhangwang I don't think that this would be a problem, because we only delete task directories -- the application directory itself is not touched. Thus, each instance, should delete and recreate a distinct set of task directories. Or do I miss something?
@jjkoshy : I have updated the patch. Would you mind taking another look?
One minor comment, LGTM otherwise.
LGTM

Passing client compatibility test: http://testing.confluent.io/confluent-kafka-branch-builder-system-test-results/?prefix=2016-10-04--001.1475600833--hachikuji--KAFKA-4165--3a6d98c/.

Passing upgrade tests: http://testing.confluent.io/confluent-kafka-branch-builder-system-test-results/?prefix=2016-10-04--001.1475604291--hachikuji--KAFKA-4165--82a40dd/

Hi @dguy , I am working on issue. I want to address following issues to make sure that I understood your points correctly: 
In `KStreamAggregateProcessor.init()`, there is a 'hard cast' from `KeyValueStore` to `CachedStateStore`:
          `((CachedStateStore) store).setFlushListener(new ForwardingCacheFlushListener<K, V>(context, sendOldValues));`

So, if the instances are for example, of type `CachingKeyValueStore`, then it would make sense. However, in other cases (ex: we try to pass user defined state store of type `KeyValueStore`) I think I will throw an exception. So while passing 'external' state store supplier, we should take care of this also.
Maybe I understood the design wrongly, please correct me if so.

Another point is:

We should give the possibility for user to select state store supplier , whether cached or not and the behavior of processor will be changed accordingly, like flushing or forwarding. Please correct me if I am wrong.
LGTM
LGTM

Ping @bbejeck @mjsax @enothereska @dguy for reviews.

Originally even for `System.out` the `close` call will be triggered, which may be blocking if people called `System.out.print..` somewhere else.

One meta comment about the re-formatting is that, mixing multiple "changes"  in one PR will make the reviews harder, as there will be more diffs to look at that may not be directly related to the core change.

For my own clarity I wanted to see where I went awry.  When `print()` is called the constructor call `KeyValuePrinter<>(keySerde, valSerde, streamName)` is used which delegates to `this(System.out, keySerde, valueSerde, streamName);` in the KeyValuePrinter class.  Since `System.out` is not null the boolean flag is never set and when `close()` is called on the processor `System.out` is closed as well. 

@guozhangwang  thanks for fixing.
LOL, sorry. 😄  Don't remember how landed on this PR, but didn't see you had closed the issue. Excuse me.
@dguy Sure, I wanted to make sure that I am on the right spot.  Thanks
LGTM
@mjsax @guozhangwang @enothereska

@guozhangwang - the ordering is not exactly as mentioned in the JIRA. I believe we need to commit all tasks before we close them. This is because commit will cause any cached state store records to be flushed to ProcessorNodes. Additionally, after closing all the tasks i've added a `producer.flush` so that any records sent during close will be flushed.
@dguy QueryableStateIntegrationTest > concurrentAccesses seems to have failed
@enothereska i ran the tests before i committed and again just now. They all passed both times, so i don't think the failure is caused by this commit.

@dguy @guozhangwang shouldn't we prevent further consumption before committing? I.e., shouldn't we close the consumer first? Is there a guarantee that as we're doing step 1. commit all, no more records come into the system?
@enothereska consumption happens in the `runLoop` and we've exited it at this point so there will be no more records
Ok, thanks. LGTM.
Thanks for the PR, this seems fine to me. @rajinisivaram and/or @granders, what do you think?
LGTM
@gwenshap Had one question, but otherwise LGTM.

@bill-warshaw Thanks for the patch. It seems that KIP-47 has not officially been voted to accept? Will you bump up the voting thread? Also, it seems the KIP wiki can have more details on the expected behavior when `log.retention.ms`, `log.retention.min.timestamp` and `log.retention.bytes` are all set. We probably want to have the community agree upon that.

The check has failed because of a unit test, it is unrelated to the changes here. The system test branch builder run I posted above has succeeded, though.

@becketqin unfortunately the voting thread has gone dormant.  I've bumped a couple times but haven't received any responses in awhile.  From the discussion thread it sounded like the community had a positive response, so I was hoping having an actual PR open would lend some weight to it.

👍  for more detail in the KIP wiki, I will add it later this week.

Thanks for the PR, LGTM.

@bill-warshaw Yeah, I guess part of the reason people are not voting is because the wiki was not clear for a brand new reader. Once the wiki is polished, the voting thread will probably revive.

@hachikuji thanks, updated that bit too.
@mjsax - it looks like you could use `StateDirectory.cleanRemovedTasks()` as it will only delete the `taskDir` if it can get the lock
We want this in trunk too, right? Also, seems like this was merged, so the PR should be closed (non-trunk PRs are not closed automatically).
Thanks @rajinisivaram, updated the PR. I ran the tests 1000 times and they all passed. cc @hachikuji

The build log is already gone, any way to rerun and see what the failures were? 
Maybe needs another merge from trunk?
@becketqin This PR is not ready for review yet. Please ignore.

@benstopford Can you take a look? 

I think the test failed in https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-git-pr-jdk7/6086/testReport/junit/kafka.admin/ReassignPartitionsClusterTest/shouldExecuteThrottledReassignment/ because the reassign command that updates quota configuration completed before the throttle config update actually took effect. Rather than changing the implementation to fix the test, I have increased the amount of data produced by the test to avoid replication completing too soon.
`QueryableStateIntegrationTest > concurrentAccesses` fails again, is this a known issue?

LGTM except I'm a bit worried about Jenkins failures, as it shows up consistently on Jenkins.

A separate question @dguy : in `RocksDBStore` we call `flush` inside the `close()` call, should we consider removing that flush inside close to be more restrict in separating the two, or is it not safe?

@guozhangwang - yes we can safely remove that `flush` as we know that we've already called `flush` prior to `close` (just committed).
The jenkins test doesn't fail when I run all the tests locally, but yes it is a concern. Should i raise a JIRA for it? Can you verify that the build passes when you run it?
LGTM. Thanks Ismael, this is much clearer.
Yes I ran it locally and cannot see it either. Let's create a JIRA for it.
Merged to trunk and 0.10.1.
Created: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-4253
yep, that seems to fix it.  Thanks.
LGTM. Thanks for the patch!
@becketqin what parts of the wiki do you think need more detail?  I took a look and I'm not sure what's missing

The build fails with a timeout. Not sure how to get rid of that.
**Build timed out (after 180 minutes)**. Marking the build as failed.
Build was aborted
@hachikuji, would you be able to review this perhaps?
@dguy @guozhangwang Updated this.
@guozhangwang @enothereska

Thanks for spotting this Rajini. It'd be nice if we could do something more deterministic, but that's not going to be easy. Not for this test at least. I've raised a jira (4266) to add something more deterministic to the other throttling tests though, so they don't suffer this problem. 
LGTM. @ijuma could you merge when you get a sec.
@ijuma This is the test corresponding to the fix in PR#1985. I have included the fix here for now so that the test passes, but I can rebase once that PR is committed.

Thanks @rajinisivaram. What is the consequence of this bug? I'm particularly interested if it's bad enough to warrant another RC. Also, it's fine to include the fix here, I can merge this PR and rebase the other one. Can you file a JIRA as well please?

@ijuma Thanks for the review. Have created JIRA KAFKA-4267.  I don't think this is bad enough to warrant another RC. The code has an impact only if a user configures a (user, clientId) quota override and then manually asks Zookeeper to delete the config change notification znode generated for the configuration change. The next broker restart wont pick up the quota override unless it is changed again.
Thanks @rajinisivaram, makes sense. @junrao, Rajini said that she can't find any code that deletes change notification znodes from Zookeeper and we were wondering if that was intentional.
Rebased on trunk after merging #1987 and edited PR description to take that into account.
Merged to trunk and 0.10.1 branches.
Got another failure for this test in trunk: https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/kafka-trunk/lastCompletedBuild/testReport/kafka.server/DelayedOperationTest/testRequestExpiry/
LGTM. I haven't been able to reproduce the failure with the latest patch.
@hachikuji for your review
